questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with cough, nasal discomfort and weight loss. He has a travel history to South America in the past. On examination, he is found to have ulcerative granulomas on his nasal and buccal mucosa. A microscopic examination of the lesion is shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Paracoccidioidomycosis

Causative agent

Thermally dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. (Option C)

Epidemiology

Confined to South America, it is called South American blastomycosis.

Route of transmission

Inhalation of spores

Clinical features

Chronic granulomatous disease of the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs.

Primary pulmonary infection spreads by the hematogenous route to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin and lymphatics.

Ulcerative granulomas of the buccal, and nasal mucosa.

Diagnosis

 

In tissue: Yeast phase - large, globose or oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell giving a mariner's wheel or pilot's wheel or Mickey Mouse appearance.


 

Culture: Mycelial phase

Treatment

 

Itraconazole is the drug of choice

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of AIDS presents to the clinic with persistent fever, significant weight loss over the past month, and cough that has worsened over the last two weeks. He resides in a rural area of Southeast Asia, where he frequently encounters bamboo rats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly. A sputum sample is collected for microbiological examination. An image is shown below. Which of the following is characteristic of the colony that is likely to grow in culture from this patient’s sputum sample?

options.label: B
options.text: Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment

options.label: D
options.text: Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour

questions.correct_answer: B. Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment
questions.explanation:
Penicillium marneffei

Characteristics

Currently, the name is changed to Talaromyces marneffei.

Thermally dimorphic fungus

Causes

Talaromycosis (Penicilliosis)

Epidemiology

Common in Southeast Asia, southern China, and northeastern India.

High incidence in AIDS and immunocompromised patients.

Reservoir

Bamboo rat

Route of transmission

Inhalation of fungal spores

No person-to-person transmission

Clinical manifestations

It affects the reticuloendothelial system, causing lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly.

Lung involvement is common.

Increased risk of dissemination in AIDS and immunocompromised individuals.

Specimens for Diagnosis

Bone marrow, blood, sputum, lymph nodes, skin lesions

Diagnosis

Culture on Sabouraud Agar:

  • Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar.

Microscopy:

  • Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores

showing a brush-like arrangement of spores

 

Additional Tests:

  • Antigen testing (urine/serum) and PCR

Treatment

Amphotericin B (IV for two weeks), followed by Itraconazole.

Others: Voriconazole, Posaconazole.

questions.text: What microscopic features are not observed when examining cultures of Histoplasma capsulatum?

A 35-year-old male from a tropical region presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a soft, fleshy nasal mass. Histopathological examination reveals thick-walled sporangia filled with endospores and hyperplastic tissue without eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It affects the mucosal membrane of the nose only.

options.label: B
options.text: The recommended course of primary treatment is Dapsone

options.label: C
options.text: The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro

options.label: D
options.text: It is not associated with contaminated water exposure

questions.correct_answer: C. The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Causative Agent
  • Rhinosporidium seeberi - eukaryotic pathogen exhibiting features of fungi and protozoa; cannot be cultured in vitro (Option C)

Pathogenesis
  • Occurs via endospores infecting traumatized mucosal surfaces, leading to hyperplastic growths and rhinosporidial polyps

Histopathology
  • Presence of thick-walled sporangia (50-1000 μm) filled with endospores (5-10 μm)
  • Surrounding tissue shows hyperplasia and infiltration by inflammatory cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells)
  • The lack of eosinophilic infiltration distinguishes it from similar infections.

Staining Techniques
  • H&E: Identifies sporangia and inflammatory response
  • PAS: Stains endospores positively
  • GMS: Visualizes fungal elements

Treatment Option

Details

Surgical Intervention

Wide surgical excision of lesions.

Cauterization of base is recommended to minimize recurrence.

Adjunctive Therapy

Postoperative Dapsone is used to prevent recurrence, though efficacy is controversial due to resistance. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A biopsy from a cutaneous lesion in a patient with suspected sporotrichosis is examined under a microscope. Which of the following findings would strongly support the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features

Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.

Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.

Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)

 

  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells. (Option C)
 

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

 

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the typical transmission route of Coccidioides immitis ?

options.label: D
options.text: Insect bite from an endemic vector

questions.correct_answer: B. Inhalation of dust containing arthrospores
questions.explanation:
Coccidioidomycosis

Causative agent

Thermally dimorphic fungus Coccidioides immitis.

Route of transmission

Inhalation of dust containing fungal arthrospores. (Option B)

Clinical features

Self-limited, flu-like fever ("valley fever" or "desert rheumatism").

Primary pulmonary infection.

Severe cases: Less than 1% develop chronic disseminated disease (coccidioidal granuloma), which can be fatal.

 

Diagnosis

 

In tissue: Spherules with a thick, doubly refractile wall, filled with endospores.

Culture: Mycelial phase with hyphae that fragment into arthrospores. Arthrospores are infective.

Skin test: Positive delayed hypersensitivity with "coccidioidin."

Treatment

 

Mild cases: Fluconazole or itraconazole.

Severe cases: Amphotericin B.

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She reports having recently cleaned out an old barn where she encountered large amounts of bird droppings. Upon examination, she has mild tachycardia and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles on auscultation. A chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and (LPCB) mount of colonies grown in culture are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Histoplasmosis

Causative Agent

Histoplasma capsulatum; thermally dimorphic fungus.

  • H. capsulatum var. capsulatum: Causes classical histoplasmosis.
  • H. capsulatum var. duboisii: Causes African histoplasmosis.

Epidemiology

Endemic to central and eastern USA; also found in Africa.

Route of transmission

Thrives in soil, decaying trees, and bird droppings.

Inhalation of fungal spores.

Clinical manifestations

Classical histoplasmosis is often asymptomatic.

Calcified lesions.

Pulmonary disease mimics tuberculosis.

Disseminated histoplasmosis can occur.

Infection of the reticuloendothelial system causes:

  • Lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anaemia

Skin and mucous membrane: Granulomatous and ulcerative lesions.

African Histoplasmosis:

  • It primarily affects the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and bones
  • Lungs are rarely involved, and disseminated cases are infrequent

Specimens for Diagnosis

Blood, urine, bone marrow, lesions

 

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells
 

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)
 

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum are helpful for immunocompromised individuals.

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B for two to four weeks followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from North America presents with cough, fever, and weight loss. Chest imaging shows focal consolidation in the lungs, and he has developed ulcerative skin lesions on his face as shown below. A skin biopsy is performed, and the sample is sent for GMS staining. An image of the GMS stain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Blastomycosis
  • ↳ Blastomycosis

  • ↳ Epidemiology Primarily found in North America; cases are also reported in Africa and Delhi, India.

  • ↳ Primarily found in North America; cases are also reported in Africa and Delhi, India.

  • ↳ Route of transmission
  • ↳ Route of transmission

  • ↳ Inhalation of fungal spores from contaminated soil.
  • ↳ Clinical manifestations Acute or chronic infection , characterised by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions with a marked preference for lungs and skin. Primary Lung Infection : Mimics tuberculosis or histoplasmosis; symptoms vary from asymptomatic to severe with focal consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscesses. Disseminated Disease : Spreads through the bloodstream, forming multiple abscesses; high fatality rate. Cutaneous Disease : Begins as a papule, forming large, ulcerative lesions, often on the face or other exposed skin.

Primary Lung Infection : Mimics tuberculosis or histoplasmosis; symptoms vary from asymptomatic to severe with focal consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscesses. Disseminated Disease : Spreads through the bloodstream, forming multiple abscesses; high fatality rate. Cutaneous Disease : Begins as a papule, forming large, ulcerative lesions, often on the face or other exposed skin.
  • ↳ Acute or chronic infection , characterised by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions with a marked preference for lungs and skin.
  • ↳ chronic infection
  • ↳ Primary Lung Infection : Mimics tuberculosis or histoplasmosis; symptoms vary from asymptomatic to severe with focal consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscesses.

Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain: Black staining of fungal cell walls. {{caption_text}} GMS answer" data-author="" data-hash="10191" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/VJTV83IbwnalK0pMJ51y1744477904.png" /> Culture : Filamentous growth with septate hyphae and round/oval conidia.

  • ↳ Microscopy :
  • ↳ Microscopy
  • ↳ Large, thick double-contoured wall, spherical yeast with a single broad-based bud. Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain: Black staining of fungal cell walls.
  • ↳ Large, thick double-contoured wall, spherical yeast with a single broad-based bud.
  • ↳ Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain: Black staining of fungal cell walls.
  • ↳ Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain: Black staining of fungal cell walls.

  • ↳ Culture
  • ↳ Filamentous growth with septate hyphae and round/oval conidia.

  • ↳ Treatment
  • ↳ Treatment
  • ↳ Treatment

  • ↳ Itraconazole: For mild to moderate cases.
  • ↳ Amphotericin B: For severe and life-threatening cases.
  • ↳ Chromoblastomycosis (Option B): It is a chronic fungal infection, that typically presents as warty, nodular skin lesions, not as ulcerative lesions. It is commonly found in tropical regions and is not associated with lung involvement or systemic symptoms like weight loss. Microscopic examination shows sclerotic bodies. This option is incorrect.
  • ↳ Chromoblastomycosis (Option B):
  • ↳ Mycotic Mycetoma (Option C): It is caused by the fungi Madurella mycetomatis. It presents as a chronic infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and sometimes bone, usually in the feet. It manifests as nodules that can develop into draining sinuses and does not typically form warty lesions or display sclerotic bodies in microscopy. This option is incorrect.
  • ↳ Mycotic Mycetoma (Option C):
  • ↳ Sporotrichosis (Option D): It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii, often occurs after a traumatic implantation and typically presents with nodular lesions that can ulcerate, forming a lymphatic spread pattern. Microscopy of sporotrichosis shows cigar-shaped yeast cells instead. This option is incorrect.
  • ↳ Sporotrichosis (Option D):

Blastomycosis

Causative Agent:

Blastomyces dermatitidis, a thermally dimorphic fungus.

Epidemiology

Primarily found in North America; cases are also reported in Africa and Delhi, India.

Route of transmission

Inhalation of fungal spores from contaminated soil.

Clinical manifestations

Acute or chronic infection, characterised by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions with a marked preference for lungs and skin.

Primary Lung Infection: Mimics tuberculosis or histoplasmosis; symptoms vary from asymptomatic to severe with focal consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscesses.

Disseminated Disease: Spreads through the bloodstream, forming multiple abscesses; high fatality rate.

Cutaneous Disease: Begins as a papule, forming large, ulcerative lesions, often on the face or other exposed skin.

 

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Large, thick double-contoured wall, spherical yeast with a single broad-based bud.
  • Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain: Black staining of fungal cell walls.
GMS answer" data-author="" data-hash="10191" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/VJTV83IbwnalK0pMJ51y1744477904.png" />

Culture:

  • Filamentous growth with septate hyphae and round/oval conidia.

Treatment

Itraconazole: For mild to moderate cases.

Amphotericin B: For severe and life-threatening cases.

questions.text: Dimorphic fungi can evade the host immune system primarily through which of the following mechanisms?

options.label: B
options.text: Conversion to a yeast form in the host

questions.correct_answer: B. Conversion to a yeast form in the host

questions.text: A 45-year-old male agricultural worker from a rural area presents with an extensive slowly growing, warty, nodular lesion on his lower leg as shown in the image below. The lesion is dark, and rough, and resembles the surface of cauliflower. He recalls injuring his leg on a thorn while working barefoot in the fields several months ago. A KOH mount of the skin specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis)

Epidemiology

It is the most common form of chromomycosis.

Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.

Tropical region.

Causative agents

Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora.

Route of transmission

Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation.

Clinical manifestation

Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower).

Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs

Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation.

Chromoblastomycosis foot" data-author="" data-hash="10182" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/XDM2CdVMChdG0KscAB1w1744476678.png" />

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy: The lesions show the presence of the fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate, called sclerotic bodies (other names: muriform bodies, copper pennies, medlar bodies).

Sclerotic cells" data-author="" data-hash="10185" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/vw70kUv1HY15bZZnjgC31744476801.png" />

Demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Treatment

Medical: Amphotericin B, thiabendazole, 5-fluorocytosine, itraconazole and (new drug) voriconazole.

Surgical excision.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with multiple light-coloured patches on his chest and back, which are more noticeable after sun exposure. The lesions are asymptomatic but have not resolved with moisturizers. An image of the Microscopic examination of skin scrapings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Test/Tool

Findings

Microscopy (Skin Scrapings)

Abundant yeast cells and short, branched filaments (yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments):

Tinea versicolor KOH." data-author="" data-hash="10095" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RrVjSljkSpVrKoq2sYTO1744469150.png" />

Spaghetti and meatball appearance under KOH microscopy:

 

Culture

Grown on Sabouraud agar with an olive oil overlay.

Versicolor SDA" data-author="" data-hash="10097" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/rHhlfhaSGBz1aVg5YagT1744469378.png" />

Wood’s Lamp Exam

Infected areas fluoresce golden-yellow under UV light.

Versicolor Wood’s Lamp " data-author="" data-hash="10098" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/EVtP4p0OtNCrspsH4Gs61744469541.jpg" />

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: It is exclusively seen in functional infections

options.label: B
options.text: It is never associated with parasitic infestations

options.label: C
options.text: It can occur in both infectious and noninfectious conditions

options.label: D
options.text: It does not involve any immune cells

questions.correct_answer: C. It can occur in both infectious and noninfectious conditions
questions.explanation:
Conditions where the phenomenon is seen

Fungal infections
  • Sporotrichosis,
  • pityrosporum folliculitis,
  • Zygomycosis,
  • candidiasis,
  • aspergillosis
  • blastomycosis.

Bacterial infections
  • Botryomycosis,
  • nocardiosis
  • actinomycosis.

Parasitic infestations
  • Orbital pythiosis,
  • strongyloidiasis,
  • schistosomiasis
  • cutaneous larva migrans.

Noninfective pathologies
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome
  • allergic conjunctival granulomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a chronic, painless nodule on his foot, which has progressively enlarged over the past year. Upon examination, he has draining sinuses with black grains in the exudate. Microscopic examination of the tissue reveals thick-walled grains and hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, (Option C) Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.

Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).

Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp. (Options A & B ruled out)

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

questions.text: Match the following: Column A (Infection category) Column B (Disease) a. Superficial (i) Dermatophytosis b. Subcutaneous (ii) White piedra c. Systemic (iii) Mycetoma d. Cutaneous (iv) Blastomycosis
questions.explanation:
Category

Diseases

Superficial (localised to the stratum corneum)
  • Pytriasis versicolor,
  • Tinea nigra,
  • white piedra, black piedra.

Cutaneous
  • Dermatophytosis,
  • Candidosis of skin, nail and mucosa.

Subcutaneous
  • Mycetoma,
  • Chromomycosis
  • Sporothicosis,
  • Phaeohyphomycosis
  • Entomophthoromycoses.

Deep or systemic (often endemic)
  • Histoplasmosis,
  • Coccidiodomycosis
  • Blastomycosis,
  • Paracoccidiodomycosis.

Opportunistic
  • Candidosis,
  • Cryptococcosis
  • Aspergillosis,
  • Penicilliosis,
  • Zygomycosis,
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia.

questions.text: Which statement is correct regarding the use of Wood’s lamp in dermatology?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not useful for diagnosing scalp infections as hair blocks fluorescence

options.label: B
options.text: It is done in a bright room using ultraviolet light

options.label: C
options.text: Normal skin will fluoresce bright pink under Wood’s lamp

options.label: D
options.text: Microsporum infections commonly fluoresce bright greenish-yellow under Wood's lamp

questions.correct_answer: D. Microsporum infections commonly fluoresce bright greenish-yellow under Wood's lamp
questions.explanation:
Infection

Cause

Color

Tinea capitis

Fungal

Blue-green

Tinea (Pityriasis) versicolor

Fungal

Yellowish green or orange

Erythrasma

Bacterial

Red

Vitiligo

Cell death

White

Porphyria cutanea tarda

Genetic or exposure

Red-pink

Pseudomonas infections

Bacterial

Green

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with hair loss and scalp lesions. A hair perforation test is performed to differentiate between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes . Which of the following statements about the hair perforation test is true?

options.label: C
options.text: Microscopically hair is examined with Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain

options.label: D
options.text: T. mentagrophytes exhibits surface erosion of the hair shaft.

questions.correct_answer: D. T. mentagrophytes exhibits surface erosion of the hair shaft.
questions.explanation:
Method

Description

Macroscopic examination

Assess the growth rate, texture, and colour on media

Urea hydrolysis test

Determines ability to hydrolyze urea

Growth on polished rice or special media

Tests the ability to grow in specific conditions

Temperature tolerance test

Assesses resistance to elevated temperatures

Nutritional requirements test

Checks requirements for specific amino acids and vitamin

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a pruritic rash in the groin area. Upon examination, the lesion is erythematous with raised borders and has a clear centre. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the anatomical classification of dermatophytosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Type

Description

Tinea barbae

Infection of the bearded areas of the face and neck (barber's itch). (Option A ruled out)

Tinea capitis

Infection of the scalp; variants include favus and kerion. (Option B ruled out)

Tinea corporis

Infection of smooth, non-hairy skin (Tinea glabrosa). (Option D ruled out)

Tinea cruris

Infection of the groin and perineum (jock itch). (Option C)

Tinea imbricata

Tropical variant of Tinea corporis with concentric scaly patches.

Tinea manuum

Infection of the hand.

Tinea pedis

Infection of the foot (athlete's foot).

Tinea unguium

Infection of the nails.

Genus

Key Characteristics

Microsporum

Predominantly macroconidia; spindle-shaped, multicellular structures; infects hair and skin.

Trichophyton

More abundant microconidia in clusters; macroconidia are thin, and elongated; include species like T. rubrum which is common in humans. Infects hair, nails and skin.

Epidermophyton

Lacks microconidia; club-shaped, multicellular macroconidia; infects skin and nails but not hair.

Features

Trichophyton

Microsporum

Epidermophyton

1. Site of infection

Hair, nail, and skin

Hair and skin only

Skin and nail only

2. Colony

Powdery pigmented

Cotton-like pigmented

Powdery greenish yellow

3. Spores

a. Microconidia

Abundant

Relatively scanty

Absent

b. Macroconidia

Pencil or cylindrical-shaped

Spindle-shaped

Club or pear-shaped

Habitat Type

Characteristics

Examples

Anthropophilic

Primarily found in humans; causes mild, chronic lesions.

T. rubrum, E. floccosum, M. audouinii

Zoophilic

Natural parasites of animals; cause severe inflammation but are treatable.

T. verrucosum, M. canis

Geophilic

Found in soil; less pathogenic to humans.

M. gypseum, T. ajelloi

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with hair loss and black dot tinea capitis. Microscopic examination of the hair reveals elongated hyphae within the hair shaft. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely condition the child has?

options.label: B
options.text: It is commonly associated with Microsporum canis

options.label: C
options.text: It typically involves Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum

options.label: D
options.text: The treatment of choice is typically 2 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. It typically involves Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum
questions.explanation:
Feature

Endothrix

Ectothrix

Hair Invasion

Inside the hair shaft

Exterior of the hair shaft

Hyphae Location

Arthroconidia inside hair

On the surface and inside the hair

Common Species

Trichophyton tonsurans, T. violaceum

Microsporum canis

Contagiousness

Less contagious

More contagious

Clinical Presentation

Black dot tinea capitis

tinea capitis" data-author="" data-hash="10128" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/IM85fCEv8PP66N9fYqsO1744473140.jpg" />

Gray patch tinea capitis

tinea capitis" data-author="" data-hash="10129" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/TNHCsgqObBSLTcN6PRuW1744473292.jpg" />

Diagnostic Features

Comma and corkscrew hairs

Perifollicular scaling

Treatment Duration

6–12 weeks

May require longer treatment

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with dark, hard nodules along his scalp hair, which he mistakenly believes to be lice nits. Upon microscopic examination, branched hyphae and arthrospores are observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Piedraia hortae (dematiaceous fungus) (Option B).

Characteristics

Affects scalp hair; it is common in individuals with long hair and poor hygiene.

Clinical Features

Hard, black nodules that may resemble lice nits; complex structure of filamentous hyphae and spores; examined using KOH shows branched hyphae and arthrospores.

Diagnosis

Direct microscopic examination:

Branched hyphae and arthrospores

Culture:

Sabouraud dextrose agar shows dark colonies.

Treatment

Antifungal shampoos or systemic antifungals; treatment efficacy may be compromised by nodules' compact nature.

Aspect

Details

Etiology

Caused by Trichosporon species, commonly Trichosporon beigelli, Trichosporon inkin (Option A ruled out).

Characteristics

Affects facial, axillary, and pubic hair; typically asymptomatic.

Clinical Features

Whitish, loosely adherent nodules consisting of arthroconidia and blastoconidia.

Diagnosis

KOH examination and culture reveal yeast-like colonies.

Treatment

Topical antifungals such as ketoconazole shampoo.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman from a tropical region presents with a brown, macular lesion on the palm of her hand. There is no itching or scaling. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings reveals brownish, branched, septate hyphae along with budding cells. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Tinea Nigra

Tinea Versicolor

Affected Area

Palms

Chest, abdomen, upper limbs, back

Lesion Appearance

Black/brown macules

Hypopigmented or discolored macules

Causative Agent

Exophiala werneckii, Exophiala castellanii

Malassezia furfur (formerly Pityrosporum orbiculare) (Option A ruled out)

Microscopy

Brown hyphae and budding cells

Yeast-like cells and short, branched filaments

Culture

Grey/black colonies on Sabouraud agar

Requires Sabouraud agar with olive oil

Wood's Lamp Findings

None

Golden-yellow fluorescence
